faculty.opportunities:
We study self-organized macroscopic waves in a giant single-celled organism, their interplay with an external driving force, and the dynamics of regeneration.

The focus is on Caulerpa, a marine green alga with differentiated organs resembling leaves, stems and roots; while an individual can exceed a meter in size, it is a single multinucleated giant cell. 

This line of research would expand our understanding of intrinsic biological clocks, their interaction with the environment, and their role in anticipatory behaviour.

A project is available, following student interest, computational (remotely), as well as in-lab (subject to Caltech policy), that could include: 

* [computational] An image analysis algorithm to computationally dissect the organ-like regions of the organism, and quantify the development of morphology over time.

* [computational; in-lab optional] Development of a computerized reactive spatio-temporal patterned illumination system, involving image analysis and illumination pattern design to be projected  on the sample. In-lab, there are optics and mechanical design related sub-projects.

* [in lab] Stress-strain measurements of blade rims to test hypotheses related to transitions in growth pattern.  

* [in lab] Studying morphogenesis and the intrinsic waves under electric perturbations.

faculty.opportunities:
Title: Relating Collective Tissue Phenomena to the Underlying Calcium Dynamics in Single Cells in a Plant Stem Cell Niche

Living Cells can exhibit measurable variation of ionic content at various timescales, from seconds to hours and days. These variations are often associated with cell-to-cell signalling and response, which are at the basis of communication and computation at the tissue level. Calcium ions (Ca2+) are frequently studied as a messenger, and are also known to play a role in the mechanical properties of cells, which in turn play a role in morphogenesis --- the generation of form.

The Shoot Apical Meristem (SAM) is the stem cell niche in land plants, from which all above-ground organs originate, namely leaves, flowers and the extension of the stem itself. Using microscopy time-lapse fluorescent imaging, and a fluorescent reporter for Ca2+ concentrations, our research group has identified and characterized three main types of Ca2+ signal patterns in the SAM: (1) single cell spikes, or twinkling (2) spontaneous global tissue oscillations, and (3) an inducible global wave-like propagation of Ca2+ cellular concentration. Studying the temporal variation of Ca2+ at single cell level throughout the tissue would allow us to further understand  these modes of Ca2+ signals, and the role they play in tissue and organismal dynamics.

The proposed project is of computational nature, primarily image and data analysis. A successful reduction of the time-lapse imaging data to temporal traces of cellular Ca2+ level would allow quantitative:

* comparison of single cell temporal pattern when twinkling, oscillation, and the stimulated wave, as well as exploring the effects of one mode over the statistics of the other; and
* study cell-cell correlations, potentially identifying spatio-temporal patterns related to cellular and regional states; this may also open the path to causal structure inference.

faculty.name: Brent Fultz
faculty.requirements: There are two possibilities. 1) Computational experience. Not so much writing new code, but sorting out workflows through different packages. 2) Laboratory chemistry. We don't do so much conventional chemical synthesis, but we use plasmas and mechanical deformation to make new materials. There is also an effort to measure physical properties by gas adsorption (think plumbing) and electrochemistry (think batteries).
faculty.opportunities: Usually the undergraduate will work on a research project funded by either NSF or DOE. The project is typically part of a Ph.D. thesis of a graduate student, who needs some help. The work may not be in the critical path, though. Reconfiguring measurement instruments and rewriting the software for them is typical project. Sometimes making electrochemical cells and testing them is a good project, but this usually requires regular presence in the lab.

faculty.name: Mario Hubert
faculty.requirements: Strong background in physics (classical physics, electrodynamics, and/or quantum mechanics) and interest in working on conceptual problems in physics. Some introductory class in philosophy of physics would be helpful.
faculty.opportunities:
There are four active research fields:
1. There are many open problems in the foundations of quantum mechanics. What is the status of the wave-function? What do different interpretations of quantum mechanics tell us about the world? Are some interpretations better than others?
2. Another topic would be classical electrodynamics. The self-interaction problem is still unsolved and alternative theories are needed. Solving the classical self-interaction problem is a promising path to solve the ultra-violet divergence in quantum field theory.
3. What are probabilities? Are probabilities subjective or objective? Probabilities are used throughout physics, and a theory of probabilities that is particularly suitable for physics is still under debate.
4. What does is mean to understand physics? This research field has become very active in the last two decades. A theory of understanding would also determine how physical theories need to be constructed.
All four areas provide plenty of opportunities to work on short and extended projects.

faculty.name: Paul Bellan
faculty.requirements: Computer skills with large data sets, some physics knowledge
faculty.opportunities:
In a new initiative between Caltech and Los Alamos National Lab (LANL),   existing experimental sets of kink instability data collected at Caltech over the past years will be archived in a manner that machine learning (ML) techniques can be applied to them. The  goal is to demonstrate ML for studying the kink instability physics, such as prediction of kink rise time and growth rate, and to compare the results with theory and simulations. 

As a first step, the existing Caltech datasets will be archived by a Caltech undergraduate at a shared drive or multiple mirror sites at Caltech and LANL. The archiving effort include turning the raw data into the uniform format of .tif without resolution reduction from the originals, and documenting the experimental conditions for each data set in Word and/or Excel including X-ray images, related diagnostic data and experimental conditions.
